title: Integration Studio—ALM Octane integration
content:
Overview

This topic presents an illustrated set of integration use cases between Service Management and Octane:

  • Portal-based Defect or Enhancement requests
  • Incident to Defect integration

The use cases in a nutshell:

Service Management:Main/IntegrateJira

Use case 1: Portal-based Defect or Enhancement requests

In this sample use case, end users who subscribe to a specific Business Service Application can report defects or request enhancements to the application by posting them via the Service Management Service Portal.

We will follow the steps below, which are performed by Eve, an employee who uses her company’s eExpense application for expense tracking and reporting. She has been frustrated that expense reporting can only be done while logged on to the eExpense web application and wishes that her company would provide an enhancement to enable native mobile access for faster expense reporting. While Eve can post the enhancement request via the Portal, her company is tracking such Application requests in a Octane system used by the Application Development team. However, the seamless integration with the Portal makes this internal detail transparent to Eve.

Service Management:Main/IntegrateJira

Step 3: Octane Feature created and confirmation provided back to the user

So far, Eve has interacted only through the Self-Service Portal. Once she submits her request, an automated workflow runs in the background to create a corresponding record in Octane, including any attachments. The following screenshot shows the Octane Feature record created to track her request. Since Eve selected Improvement as the issue type, the Octane record is appropriately tagged to align with the development backlog.

Step 4: Status confirmation

While the record above is created behind the scenes, the Portal provides validation and confirmation back to Eve, letting her know that an enhancement record has been logged for review by the application development team. An enhancement ticket ID from Octane is even provided back to Eve so that she can use it for future reference.


Step 5: Behind the scenes - association of the Octane ticket with the Service Management Request ticket

While at this point the ownership of the enhancement has been passed over, we should also note that details of the association between the Octane Feature and Eve’s Portal request have been logged. In reviewing the Request record, Service Management Service Desk agents can find a direct reference to the related Octane Feature that's tracking the potential work to enhance the application.

The screen below shows details about Octane’s response in the creation of its Feature record as they are recorded in the Request’s Offering section. Note some specific fields of interest, such as:

  • Remote ID: The Octane ID that's tracking the enhancement
  • Remote status: The status of the Octane record (at that point in time)
  • Remote system: The name of the system to integrate with
  • URL: A URL that takes the agent directly to the Octane Feature for tracking

The creation of a defect in Octane can happen in the same way as raising an enhancement request. Select the “Report a defect” offering in the portal. The main difference is, the Enhancement request gets automatically resolved, but the defect might stay open for analysis and troubleshooting by the helpdesk to answer questions from the application management team working with Octane.

Use case 2: Change request to Enhancement

This use case describes how to create a new feature in Octane based on a Change request in Service Management. Within a change record, the change owner might want to create a new feature in Octane. To do so, the change owner can click the button Create Feature. The system will then create a new feature in Octane to track the requirement and put the details as external reference into the change record.

Use case 3: Incident/Request/Problem to defect

In this use case, Stephen reviews the Incident where a user reports an application malfunction. After analysis, Stephen confirms that the issue is an application defect, which needs to be fixed by the application team.

Stephen assigns the ticket to the RnD group and enters a comment to the record. The assignment of the Incident triggers the execution of an integration, which creates a new defect in Octane.

 Incidents are used in this example. However, the defect creation into Octane can be triggered from Requests, Incidents, Problems, and Changes in Service Management. Triggering the integration from Studio apps requires some small changes to the integrations.

Tip: You can also create a new feature request in Octane in a similar way.


After he clicks ADD & SAVE RECORD, the defect is created in the Octane system. Within the Incident in Service Management, we track the following data from the Octane record.

  • Remote ID: The Octane ID that's tracking the Defect
  • Remote status: The status of the Octane record (at that point in time)
  • URL: A URL that takes the agent directly to the Octane Issue for tracking.

Clicking the URL in the Incident opens the record in Octane. The Incident details as well as the comments are transferred to the Octane system.

Use case 4: Keep exchanged records in sync

To get the latest updates from Octane reflected in Service Management, several options exist:

  • Click a button that pulls data from Octane on demand
  • Set up a webhook in Octane, which automatically pushes changes to Service Management
  • Schedule the scenario to regularly pull the recently modified records

To get the latest status from Octane reflected in Service Management, one option is to add a button “Pull ALM Update”. Clicking the button will pull the status from Octane and update the record in Service Management.

Example:

Clicking the button in Service Management will show the new Octane status in the Service Management record.

In addition, a comment is added to the Discussions section.

Set up the integration

As an example, the procedure below will set up the integration to implement the Incident Exchange use case.

Prepare an integration user

Perform the following steps to prepare an integration user: 

  1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user.

  2. Service Management:Main/IntegrateJira

Export the certificate from the Octane instance

To connect to Octane, you will need to upload their root CA certificate in a later step. To get the certificate from Octane, you can export the certificate from the browser as base64 encoded to a file.

Configure Service Management

Create an endpoint

Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:

  1. Log in to the Agent Portal as the tenant admin.
  2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.
  3. Click Add.
  4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint (for example, Octane), and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.
  5. Click Configure and complete the fields depending on whether the endpoint needs to use the OPB Agent.

If the endpoint doesn't need to use the OPB Agent, complete these fields.

Example:

Create an integration

Create an integration and configure one or more scenarios to define the business logic for forwarding tickets and synchronizing ticket updates to Octane. The Octane connector has three predefined scenario templates:

  • Enhancement tracking
  • Defect tracking
  • Pull status updates

In the following steps, you'll create an integration with these predefined templates.

  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio. 
  2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
  3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the current Service Management system and activate the integration.
  4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add to add a mapping.
  5. Select ALM Octane (under OpenText) as the connector, select the Octane endpoint that you created earlier, and then enter an alias for the mapping.
  6. Click Save.

Configure the scenarios

Perform the following steps to add the scenarios to the integration:

  1. Click Add scenario. 
  2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, Enhancement tracking.
  3. In the Template field, select Enhancement tracking (under OpenText ALM Octane) from the list. 
  4. Click Save to add the scenario.
  5. (Optional) Repeat the steps above to add the rest of the scenarios listed in the table below.
 Using templates will make the integration configuration easier than starting from scratch. If you don't select this option, you'll have to manually add your own logic, starting from a blank page. 

Use the following out-of-the-box scenarios for this integration. The following table describes the actions required for each of the scenarios before you run the integration.

Use the scenarios

Use case 1 – Portal-based Defect or Enhancement requests

Having set up the endpoint and the integration, the final step is about the business logic to trigger the integration. To see this use case working, a Catalog Offering with a Fulfillment Task Plan that invokes the appropriate Octane integration is needed.

As you may recall, in the Use Case example, Eve submitted an Improvement Request via an Offering associated with the eExpense application:

In the newly created Offering:

  • We have designated Application as a related Service Definition.
  • We have also set Subscription as the value for the Required asset information. This means that users submitting the Defect or Enhancement request for eExpense must have specified the Subscription to the Application service that they have been granted.

Specify user options

Specific user options will be added to collect information from the user as well as to store results provided back by Octane during its creation of an issue record. You can find the following options in the screens below:

Service Management:Main/IntegrateJira

Define a task plan

In this step, create a Task Plan that triggers the Octane integration. The full task plan will include a few automated tasks as shown below:

  1. The first task creates the Octane Issue. 

  2. A condition task then checks whether the Octane Issue was successfully created.

    Service Management:Main/IntegrateJira

                    

Task 1 – Create Enhancement in ALM System:

  1. Add an Automated Task.
  2. Give the task a title, description and assignment group.
  3. Select Call Integration Studio as the Business Rule for the Task.
  4. Select integration Octane and scenario Enhancement tracking.
  5. Save the task.

Service Management:Main/IntegrateJira

To send additional comments from Service Management to Octane, add the following business rule to the Request entity in Studio.

The condition in this example is:
${current_update.Comments.IsChanged && current_user.Upn != 'intJan' && lookup('ExternalReference','RemoteSystem','EntityType','Request','EntityId',entity.Id,'RemoteSystem','Octane')=='Octane'}
This means when:

  • a comment is added 
  • and the update is not coming from the integration user configured in the Integration Studio
  • and there is an Octane record in the ExternalReference entity

then the integration is triggered, and comments are sent to Octane.

Use case 4 – Keep exchanged records in sync

This use case can be achieved in 2 ways:

  • Pull updates on demand
  • Make Octane push the updates to Service Management

You can implement both options or just one of them to receive updates from Octane.

Pull updates on demand

To get the latest status updates from Octane reflected in Service Management, perform the following steps.

Service Management:Main/IntegrateJira

Process incoming events

To use this method, you must set up and configure the scenario “Process incoming events” as described in the “Set up the scenario” section.

  1. Ensure the listener details are configured.

    Example:

  2. Create a Webhook in Octane and configure your trigger parameters. Ensure that at least the Octane record ID is sent to Service Management.

The scenario extracts the Record ID from the received payload, gets the latest status of the modified item from Octane, and then updates the Service Management record accordingly.
